d: A gradual increase in the overall temperature of the earth's atmosphere generally attributed to the greenhouse effect caused by increased levels of carbon dioxide, CFCs, and other pollutants.
e: The company is deeply concerned by the effects of global warming caused by the greenhouse effect.

d: Of the color between blue and yellow in the spectrum; colored like grass or emeralds.
e: the leaves are bright green

d: The trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's lower atmosphere, due to the greater transparency of the atmosphere to visible radiation from the sun than to infrared radiation emitted from the planet's surface.
e: Scientists predict that this increase may enhance the greenhouse effect making the planet warmer.

d: Water held underground in the soil or in pores and crevices in rock.
e: They can contaminate underlying soils and groundwater or contaminate storm water which travels to bodies of surface water.

d: The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism.
e: wild chimps in their natural habitat

d: A substance that is toxic to plants, used to destroy unwanted vegetation.
e: farmers sprayed a protected wildflower meadow with herbicide

d: A place to dispose of refuse and other waste material by burying it and covering it over with soil, especially as a method of filling in or extending usable land.
e: landfill sites

d: A colorless, odorless flammable gas which is the main constituent of natural gas. It is the simplest member of the alkane series of hydrocarbons.
e: Other trace gases include methane, nitrous oxide, carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, and ozone.

d: The energy released during nuclear fission or fusion, especially when used to generate electricity.
e: All the steps in the complex process of creating nuclear energy entail environmental hazards.

d: Relating to or derived from living matter.
e: organic soils

d: A layer in the earth's stratosphere at an altitude of about 10 km (6.2 miles) containing a high concentration of ozone, which absorbs most of the ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth from the sun.
e: In the absence of the ozone layer harmful ultraviolet radiation is able to reach the surface of the Earth in higher doses.

d: A substance used for destroying insects or other organisms harmful to cultivated plants or to animals.
e: Once volatilized, a pesticide can move in air currents away from the treated surface.

d: A liquid mixture of hydrocarbons that is present in certain rock strata and can be extracted and refined to produce fuels including gasoline, kerosene, and diesel oil; oil.
e: Liquid paraffin is a mixture of liquid hydrocarbons obtained from petroleum.

d: A substance that pollutes something, especially water or the atmosphere.
e: chemical pollutants

d: The presence in or introduction into the environment of a substance or thing that has harmful or poisonous effects.
e: the level of pollution in the air is rising

d: The emission of energy as electromagnetic waves or as moving subatomic particles, especially high-energy particles which cause ionization.
e: Because it uses sound waves instead of radiation, ultrasound is safer than X-rays.

d: A luxuriant, dense forest rich in biodiversity, found typically in tropical areas with consistently heavy rainfall.
e: save the rainforests

d: Convert (waste) into reusable material.
e: car hulks were recycled into new steel

d: (of a contract, agreement, etc.) capable of being renewed.
e: the 30-day truce is renewable by mutual agreement

d: Fog or haze combined with smoke and other atmospheric pollutants.
e: exhaust emissions are mainly responsible for the smog

d: Relating to or determined by the sun.
e: solar radiation

d: Able to be maintained at a certain rate or level.
e: sustainable fusion reactions

d: Poisonous.
e: the dumping of toxic waste

d: Waste, especially industrial waste, that is hazardous to human health or the environment and which requires special facilities for its disposal; also occasionally as a count noun.
Use or expend carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose.
e: we can't afford to waste electricity

d: Land consisting of marshes or swamps; saturated land.
e: the draining of British wetlands

d: Wild animals collectively; the native fauna (and sometimes flora) of a region.
e: you can watch the wildlife

d: A building with sails or vanes that turn in the wind and generate power to grind grain into flour.
e: In the past windmills were used to grind corn into flour.

d: A body of permeable rock which can contain or transmit groundwater.
e: Because of the long residence times typical of most bodies of groundwater, contaminated aquifers are not readily restored by natural processes.

d: The envelope of gases surrounding the earth or another planet.
e: part of the sun's energy is absorbed by the earth's atmosphere

d: (of a substance or object) capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms.
e: consumers have forced a shift to more biodegradable products

d: The variety of life in the world or in a particular habitat or ecosystem.
e: To discover the patterns of biodiversity, information on biodiversity has to be collected.

d: A colourless, odourless gas produced by burning carbon and organic compounds and by respiration. It is naturally present in air (about 0.03 per cent) and is absorbed by plants in photosynthesis.
e: This fixed air is carbon dioxide, into which carbonates decompose when heated.

d: A colourless, odourless toxic flammable gas formed by incomplete combustion of carbon.
e: Other trace gases include methane, nitrous oxide, carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, and ozone.

d: A substance capable of causing cancer in living tissue.
e: The combination of cigarette smoking and exposure to many occupational carcinogens increases risk of cancer.

d: The weather conditions prevailing in an area in general or over a long period.
e: our cold, wet climate

d: A combustible black or dark brown rock consisting mainly of carbonized plant matter, found mainly in underground deposits and widely used as fuel.
e: a coal fire

d: Decayed organic material used as a plant fertilizer.
e: cover with a layer of fine compost

d: Prevention of wasteful use of a resource.
A person who advocates or acts for the protection and preservation of the environment and wildlife.
e: conservationist groups

d: A polluting or poisonous substance that makes something impure.
e: people were exposed to airborne contaminants

d: The action or state of making or being made impure by polluting or poisoning.
e: the risk of contamination by dangerous bacteria

d: The action of clearing a wide area of trees.
e: a key aim is to try to halt widespread deforestation in the Amazon

d: (of an article) intended to be used once, or until no longer useful, and then thrown away.
e: disposable diapers

d: The state of being diverse; variety.
e: there was considerable diversity in the style of the reports

d: The branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
e: the marine ecosystem of the northern Gulf had suffered irreparable damage

d: The production and discharge of something, especially gas or radiation.
e: the effects of lead emission on health

d: (of a species) seriously at risk of extinction.
e: legislation to protect endangered species

d: The strength and vitality required for sustained physical or mental activity.
e: changes in the levels of vitamins can affect energy and well-being

d: The surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates.
e: survival in an often hostile environment

d: A person who is concerned with or advocates the protection of the environment.
e: the environmentalist movement

d: The process of eroding or being eroded by wind, water, or other natural agents.
e: the problem of soil erosion

d: (of a species, family, or other group of animals or plants) having no living members; no longer in existence.
e: trilobites and dinosaurs are extinct

d: The fact or process of a species, family, or other group of animals or plants becoming extinct.
e: preventing the extinction of this unique frog will require the restoration of ponds and surrounding habitats

d: A natural fuel such as coal or gas, formed in the geological past from the remains of living organisms.
e: So burning coal or oil, which releases carbon from when the fossil fuel was formed, has a serious global warming effect.

d: Relating to or produced by the internal heat of the earth.
e: some 70% of Iceland's energy needs are met from geothermal sources
